instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: Hello guys i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> no <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> , after some trouble shoot i find out that  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL>  as soon as it gets into <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> send all to hell , if i remove <RESISTOR>R7954</RESISTOR> , i get  a <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and working s0 rails , no fan spin ,  i did replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> no result , i did remove <TRANSISTOR>Q9607</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U9950</CHIP> to see if problem was ahead , but no , i still dont check all resistors around <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> , i did follow this problem to this location from long way , and i got burn. plz help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: i just check all resistors around <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> they are fine

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
with <RESISTOR>R7954</RESISTOR> removed

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0.07v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present

with <RESISTOR>R7954</RESISTOR>

fan spins then stops , then spins , then stop.
no <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: i did remove <RESISTOR>R7974</RESISTOR> to disable the contact between <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> problem is not on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> area since <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> remain 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
i just try another <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> becase of other duke post advice to do that if we see a fans that spins and stops , i did check current sense all resistors on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> they are ok 

still nothing....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: all i can think now is check all PGOODS and resitors? or maybe surrender jaja

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
This has nothing to do with <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL>, by removing this resistor to <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> the system will never make <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> good high resulting in the system never completing its power sequencing

Basically (with <RESISTOR>R7974</RESISTOR> on the board) you will get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> but the system is power cycling.

Bios area looking OK? <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> area looking OK?
Resistance to ground (in Ohm) on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>?

This could very well be a dead GPU as well, resistance to ground (once again in Ohm) on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> = 13.4ohm
​​​​​​<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 8.0ohm

<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> area looks good , bios area looks good no red pobre points around

other detail is i removed some destroyed caps but i did not find shorts on those lines
<CAPACITOR>C3701</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C3730</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C9710</CAPACITOR>

the board was cleaned from other tec before i put my hand on it , he dont do soldering so im sure he did not replace anything
but he clean with paint tinner not ultrasonic.

i should try ultrasonic?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: If the fan spins then <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> must be present and that also means <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> will be there. Go back and check your measurements.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
i did re check is not there , fan spins and stops.
voltage is fluctuating.
i have no <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>
[B]i cant start all over again with readings {big mistake sorry i did want it to write : i can start all over again with readings , no i cant }[/B] , i want to find out if there is something that i can do because i have a pile of boards that do stuff like this now like 6 diferent models and i cant fix.

RTC is present
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>5V_SUS</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present
3.4v fo green l ight is present
ocilloscope lines look normal on clock circuit
there is no red probe points for extra clues
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> was replaced
i check current sense resistors

<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> enable is not there

Fan dont spin do quarter fan

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> = 13.4ohm
​​​​​​<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 8.0ohm

Where do i go from here?
,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> will be there but only for a split second until it power cycles again. Could very well be possible that your multimeter does not catch this
If the fan spins even for a split second it means you had <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

If you really believe there is no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, what is the resistance to ground in Ohms on this line?
With nowhere else to go you might just want to check the resistance to ground on all power lines, report back those with less then 100Ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> problem
threads.message: The real question is does CPU Vcore pulse? If the fan moves all voltages are OK and the last one that needs to appear is CPU Vcore. Check carefully with a multimeter but the pulses are very short and on auto ranging meters pretty impossible to catch. Use a scope to see the pulsing.
